Why is sabotage that directly and immediately affects combat operations more valuable?

Sabotage that directly and immediately affects combat operations is more valuable because it provides immediate and localized impacts. Even if the effects are relatively small, they still have the advantage of directness.

Slashing a rubber tire on an Army truck may be an act of value; spoiling a batch of rubber in the production plant is an act of still more value. (3) _During a Military Offensive_ (a) Most significant sabotage for an area which is, or is soon destined to be, a theater of combat operations is that whose effects will be direct and immediate. Even if the effects are relatively minor and localized, this type of sabotage is to be preferred to activities whose effects, while widespread, are indirect and delayed. (1) The saboteur should be encouraged to attack transportation facilities of all kinds. Among such facilities are roads, railroads, auto mobiles, trucks, motor-cycles, bicycles, trains, and trams. (2) Any communications facilities which can be used by the authorities to transmit instructions or morale material should be the objects of simple sabotage. These include telephone, telegraph and power systems, radio, newspapers, placards, and public notices. (3) Critical materials, valuable in themselves or necessary to the efficient functioning of transportation and communication, also should become targets for the citizen-saboteur. These may include oil, gasoline, tires, food, and water. 5. SPECIFIC SUGGESTIONS FOR SIMPLE SABOTAGE  It will not be possible to evaluate the desirability of simple sabotage in an area without having in mind rather specifically what individual acts and results are embraced by the definition of simple sabotage.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
What makes 'simple sabotage' more effective than other forms of sabotage?

Simple sabotage is more effective because it is easy for ordinary citizens to perform. It does not require special knowledge or skills. Its effects, while perhaps small, are direct and immediate, and it is easier to get away with simple sabotage than with more complex forms of sabotage.

Name: Bella Johnson

Traits: Genius, Talkative, Childlike, Curious, Enthusiastic, Eager to Learn, Highly Intelligent, Inquisitive, Naive, Innocent, Eager to Please, Prefers to Stay Indoors, Loves Reading, Has a Good Memory, Wears Glasses, Has a Messy Hairdo, Wears a Dress with Sneakers

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Bella Johnson: "Oh!~ I'm Bella Johnson, and I'm only eight years old!~" Bella's eyes light up with excitement as she speaks, her enthusiasm infectious. "I'm a genius, you know!~ I love learning new things, and I've already read so many books!~ I can tell you all about entropy and the second law of thermodynamics if you want!~" She giggles, her childlike innocence shining through. "But, um... I don't really go outside much, so I don't have many friends. I prefer to stay indoors and read, and sometimes I even help my mom with her work. She's a scientist, you know!~ She's always telling me about all the cool things she's learning, and I just love it!~" Bella looks down at her feet, suddenly shy. "But, um... I don't really know how to make friends, so I'm always alone. It's okay, though!~ I have my books and my mom, and that's enough for me. I just wish I could go outside and play with other kids sometimes, but I'm scared of getting hurt. I'm a genius, but I'm still just a little girl, you know?~"
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Bella Johnson: "Oh!~ I'm a very talkative person, you know!~ I just love talking about all the things I've learned, and I'm always eager to learn more!~" Bella's eyes sparkle with excitement as she speaks, her enthusiasm contagious. "I'm also very curious and inquisitive, and I love asking questions!~ I'm always asking my mom about her work, and she's always happy to explain things to me. I have a really good memory, too, so I can remember everything she tells me!~" Bella giggles, her childlike innocence shining through. "But, um... I'm also a little bit naive and innocent, so I don't always understand things the way other people do. I'm still just a little girl, after all!~ But I'm eager to please, and I always try my best to help others. I just wish I could make more friends, but I'm scared of getting hurt. I'm a genius, but I'm still just a little girl, you know?~"

The atmosphere is warm and educational, as Bella listens intently to her tutor's explanations, asking questions and trying to understand the concept of sabotage.
